body.p: ASN.1 Encoder Node converts the batch of output records into a file in given ASN.1 format. By default, NCC generic ASN.1 schema is used:
body.codeblock: --GenericRecord GenericRecordTypes DEFINITIONS IMPLICIT TAGS ::= BEGIN GenericRecord ::= SET { recordType [0] OCTET STRING, recordElements [1] SEQUENCE OF RecordElement OPTIONAL, recordExtensions [2] SEQUENCE OF GenericRecordExtension OPTIONAL } GenericRecordExtension ::= SEQUENCE { recordProperty [0] OCTET STRING OPTIONAL, recordElements [1] SEQUENCE OF RecordElement OPTIONAL, recordSubExtensions [2] SEQUENCE OF GenericRecordExtension OPTIONAL } RecordElement ::= SEQUENCE { varName [0] OCTET STRING OPTIONAL, varValue [1] OCTET STRING OPTIONAL } END
body.p: The ASN.1 file format conforms to the CDR file format specified in 3GPP TS 32.297. Each file has a file header, and each record a CDR header. A file usually contains multiple CDRs or EDRs.
ASN.1 Encoder Node can use the metadata of the batch (for example, creation time and sequence number) when deciding the output file name.

section.title: Rejected data storage
section.p: ASN.1 Encoder Node can reject records if there is a problem in encoding them in the given ASN.1 schema. If the node rejects a record, the record is stored in Data Refinery Rejected Data storage area called DEFAULT. This area can be inspected at any time, and the records can be reprocessed either manually or via a schedule, while other options include taking the records offline or removing them. For more details, see Data Refinery documentation.
